docs.lead_paragraph: With just over a week before Election Day to attract voters in a tight race, the New York Senate candidates released a flurry of new advertisements as they traveled through parts of the state mining for votes among women, Catholics and the elderly. Their appearances and advertisements reaffirmed their stated intentions to battle using the airwaves and old-fashioned stumping for voters in upstate New York, a traditionally Republican stronghold but a region that according to a series of polls, Hillary Rodham Clinton is strongly contesting.

headline.main: Flurry of Ads and Speeches In Last Week of Senate Race

docs.abstract: New York State Senate candidates Rick Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton release flurry of new advertisements as they travel through parts of state during last week of campaign; photo (M)

byline.original: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD with DEAN E. MURPHY

docs.lead_paragraph: Janet Grillo eats organic food, does not smoke or drink and keeps abreast of the latest health news. Yet Ms. Grillo, a 41-year-old independent film producer in Los Angeles, cannot remember the last time she had a complete physical exam, probably when her mother took her to a pediatrician. ''If I'm feeling sick, it's echinacea and early to bed. I think part of the reason I never go is because I get a yearly gynecologic exam and mistake that for accounting for all of my key organs,'' Ms. Grillo said. ''I know it doesn't make sense, but who has time? My own health care lags far behind that of my son.''

headline.main: Major Medical Mystery: Why People Avoid Doctors

docs.abstract: Sociologists and medical clinicians seeking to bolster preventive medicine are trying to figure out why so many people are reluctant to see a doctor; public health experts agree that many people who have money, health insurance and access to good medical centers are choosing not to go for checkups; photos; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Power to the people was Al Gore's cry today as he trundled across the fading emerald farmland of Wisconsin in his ongoing struggle to blunt the appeal of Ralph Nader and keep traditionally Democratic states in his column. ''You have the power to overrule the special interests if you will exercise that power,'' he said at an enthusiastic rally to more than a thousand people packed into a stuffy high school gymnasium here tonight.

headline.main: Seeking Wisconsin Votes, Gore Sounds Populist Note

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore campaigns in Wisconsin in ongoing struggle to blunt appeal of Ralph Nader and keep traditionally Democratic states in his column; sounds populist themes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, doctors told John S. Williams that they had run out of ways to help him. Mr. Williams, 41, the father of five children, had suffered since the age of 18 from Crohn's disease, an inflammatory disorder of the intestines. Repeated operations had removed so much of his small intestine that he could no longer absorb nutrients from food and needed intravenous feeding 16 hours a day.
docs.abstract: Federal Medicare program will now pay for intestinal transplants at certain hospitals, a step that will make procedure available to more patients, since private health insurers and state Medicaid programs usually follow Medicare's lead; doctors estimate that 13,000 Americans would be eligible for transplants under new guidelines: children, and young and middle-age adults who have lost intestinal function becauses of disease, injury or abnormalities at birth and who cannot survive even with intravenous feeding; two-thirds of recipients so far are children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after violent demonstrations in Seattle disrupted the World Trade Organization's meeting of ministers and shredded its image, the group's leader, Mike Moore, is still trying to pick up the pieces. The public dissatisfaction over further trade liberalization without accompanying attention to openness and environmental, safety and labor issues frayed an organization already shaken by a divisive fight for its top job -- a post Mr. Moore took up just three months before the Seattle talks collapsed.

headline.main: Patching Up Morale at the World Trade Organization

docs.abstract: Violent demonstrations that disrupted World Trade Organization's meeting of ministers in Seattle a year ago continue to preoccupy organization and its leader, Mike Moore; public dissatisfaction over further trade liberalization without accompanying attention to openness and environmental, safety and labor issues frayed organization already shaken by divisive fight for its top job--a post Moore assumed three months before Seattle talks collapsed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attention deficit disorder is a good thing? Michael Zane, the kinetic founder of the Kryptonite Bike Lock Corporation, believes it is. After fighting what had been diagnosed as depression for most of his life, Mr. Zane was told by a psychiatrist six years ago that the true diagnosis was attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, known as A.D./H.D., or A.D.D. Mr. Zane was 46 at the time, and the psychiatrist prescribed a combination of Ritalin and Prozac.

headline.main: Making a Plus of the Deficit in A.D.D.

docs.abstract: Increasing number of people, including mental health professionals, suggest that having attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder may explain some people's extraordinary abilities, and may even improve their lives; Michael Zane, founder of Kryptonite Bike Lock Corp, says having ADD has led to his success; he says he finds his considerable energy harnessed, his self-esteem improved; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey, where three of five voters are unaffiliated with a major party, has long been seen as an island of moderation in the liberal Northeast. But Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate, has built his candidacy on the belief that liberalism is back. He campaigns for huge spending increases and new federal programs in education, health care and long-term care. For almost every problem -- from inner-city poverty to suburban sprawl -- he proposes a costly government solution.

headline.main: In New Jersey, Voters' Shifting Priorities Set Tone of Senate Contest

docs.abstract: New Jersey, where three of five voters are unaffiliated with major party, has long been seen as an island of moderation in liberal Northeast; New Jersey voters, in poll after poll, say that they are in favor of increased Federal government spending and an activist Federal government; this indicates that Democratic Senatorial candidate Jon S Corzine should win election but as campaign nears an end, Republican candidate Repr Robert D Franks's call for moderation is narrowing Corzine's lead; photo (M)
